projects.name: Aegis Fun Management Ltd
description: The design is for a fund management organization in terms of spatial planning and creating a contemporary plush office environment that would inspire its workers and motivate its investors.

The use of the primary colours of the organization and an open planned office environment with transparent separations to create the hierarchy was a fundamental design approach in creating the ambiance and feel the organization was pursuing.

Diffused lighting with purpose design lighting fixtures and designer contemporary furniture adds and compliments the primary goals of the organization in terms of its principal objectives of being a modern transparent.
Built Area : 6000 Sq.ft.

projects.name: Entrance Gateways to the UNESCO World Heritage City of Anuradhapura
description: This competition winning design is an Entrance gateway to the sacred area of the Ancient Kingdom of Anuradhapura the first capital of current day Sri Lanka. The Entrance gateway is a point of transition designed to capture the mind of the entrant and transform his state of mind to a more focused mind-set with respect and reverence.

The entrance gateway designs consist of three gateways (selected from a total of six) that derive from a cohesive singular conceptual theme. However each gateway has also evolved through contextual realities and inspirations that are unique to each one.
Each gateway has historical, religious symbolism however also relating to contemporary Sri Lanka.
The three sites chosen from given option are;
1. Eastern Entrance – Lion Pillar
2. Southern Entrance – Deke Kanuwa
3. North Eastern entrance – Malvatu Oya
The concept of the entrance gateway project is
Celebration to Serenity.

Celebration to serenity is a celebration of a rich cultural heritage that created a civilisation which evolved through Buddhism. This celebration ultimately culminates in serenity, the essence of the Buddhist philosophy where on ultimately seeks serenity.

projects.name: Assidua Technologies (Pvt) Ltd
description:
Assidua Technologies is a high end industrial UPS supply tech company

The diversification from Industrial UPS to other computer hardware was the necessity for a customer oriented space to showcase there additional products.

The concept for the design was creating a dynamic space that is visually enhancing and bright that reflects the product that are being retailed by the company. The stark white, red, blue and the gloss finishes embodies the corporate colours and textures of the organisations

projects.name: Caravan Pastry Outlets
description: The project was rebranding an existing brand that retailed in confectionaries and pastries. The design challenge was to convert rented spaces to pastry shops within a 4 week time period inclusive of design and fabrication. As the spaces were rented, removable nut and bolt fabrication was incorporated into the design for re-fabrication if necessary.

The project is novel in Sri Lanka in terms of its design and its implementation bringing in a contemporary feel and internationalizing of design through the consumer food retail industry in Sri Lanka.

projects.name: Hatch Space
description: Located in the commercial heart of Colombo, Hatch aims to redefine the future of work by providing a vibrant, cost-effective, inspiring and convenient workspace for entrepreneurs, creators, professionals and business enterprises in Sri Lanka.The Hatch community has the option to choose from a range of flexible plans, including hot desks, dedicated workspaces and private offices. This enables businesses to scale up or down at short notice without having to move from one location to another as in a traditional business environment.
The community has direct access to the best tools, local and international mentors who are specialists in their fields and introductions to a range of start-up funds to realise their full potential.

The facility will houses over 600 workspaces, meeting rooms, auditoriums event spaces, cafeterias, coffee shops, nap rooms, breakout areas, fully functioning reprographics, video audio facilities and fabrication labs.

projects.name: Jewellery Store and Office Building
projects.location: R.A De Mel Mawatha, Colombo, Sri Lanka
description: A Ground plus Five Level Retail and office Development based on R.A. De Mel Mawatha in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The Architecture used, portrays a fusion of Modern and Neo Colonial classical architectural elements fusing different timelines through space as a part of the clients visual idea.  The ground floor consist of a cement based fair faced cut jewel box representing the Jewellery store and three floors above incorporates a modern office building.

The use of polished cement rendered walls was used to create a sense of antiquity depicting a jewellery box. The elements of the louvers systems is conceptualized and used to fuse the historic and the modern together as well as to filter the sunlight penetrating in to the internal spaces.

projects.name: 7.7 p House
description: Built on 7.7 perches of land. The conflict between the requirement and spatial creation was unavailability of horizontal space. Due to certain requirements in terms of the brief the design has been split into segments in terms of level configurations. The design encompasses a vertical cube of three levels and an L shaped block of two levels. These two elements are fused and bounded by a vertical courtyard. The ground level includes the carport and entrance foyer and gives a separation in level from the living spaces. At level one the open plan living dining fuse the front and rear gardens with the central courtyard bringing in subtle monochrome light that reflects off the cement rendered floors. The aspect of cross ventilation too works through the spaces due to this connectivity and the courtyard acts as a vacuum for the hot air at the lower levels to pass through the roof terrace level. The large Pantry and kitchen gives opportunity for the service requirements.

projects.name: Brick House
description: Tightly knit on a 6 perch block, the house sits facing a 20 acres marshland with water and nature as a part of its landscape.

The house is raised 1.5m above the existing landscape due to the flooding in the rainy season. Brick, unpainted soffits with bare concrete, steel framed window systems give a sense of robustness to the design and sync with its natural surroundings.

Two blocks of 3 levels and 2 levels in a split format is fused through a stairwell. Brick fenestrations in the East and West of the house defuses and percolates the harsh sunlight and filterers it into the internal spaces.
The house comprises, 4 bedrooms, living and dining with an open planed pantry, workshop and a roof terrace for gardening at a higher level.

projects.name: University of Indic and Buddhist Studies
description: The design is a researched based University emphasizing the teachings of Buddhist and Eastern philosophies, projecting peace and Reconciliation through education.

The university consist of four faculties of academic study and accommodation for 2000 students. A Sports stadia, international library, banks, shopping arcade and a convention centre with a transportation node is its urban proposal.

The design is conceptualised through the projections of spirituality and its connections with the environment. It is a landscape oriented design that evolves from the landscape of the context. The project currently is at its schematic level.

projects.name: Pivots and Boxes House
description: The Design is a house for a professional couple on 9.5 perches of Land.

The requirement of privacy in terms of the residential use as well as two office spaces and a semiprivate entertainment areas was inspired through the composition of elements using fenestrations and the existing greenery that composed a large jack fruit tree at the entrance area.
The servicing of the entertainment areas and the residential spaces has been utilized through the use of two staircases that have separate entrances and access.
The clients intention to have privacy and yet have an engagement with the street, projected the design to have permeability to the street front.

projects.id: 11 Office - Demasu Group Shared Office Spaces
projects.name: Demasu Group Shared Office Spaces
description: This commercial project is located in the dense urban commercial district of the main business district of Colombo, Sri Lanka. The rise in demand for shared work space instigated this project.The lack of views to focus the building resulted in the design decision to wrap the building in a vegetated skin to filter the natural light through to the interior work spaces. The light quality and the visibility of trees and vegetation is scientifically proven to be a stimulant of efficient work.The 9th floor accommodates rentable apartments for the occupants of the office space, with views toward the busy city.The facade is an exploration into commercial tropical modernist architecture.

projects.id: 12 Office - Office Building for Malkey Rent a Car
projects.name: Office Building for Malkey Rent-A-Car
description: The Office building is an attachment to the existing office operation which has been functioning as a part of a colonial house over a period of 30 years. Comprising 12,000 square feet of new office space the operational aspects of the business has been brought into the new building and thereby realizing the house for its generic use.
The façade has been treated in dual layer fenestrations and greenery owing to the fact that west orientation has been determined by the restriction of site.
Interior greenery has been introduced to give a sense of environmental synergy for the staff.

projects.id: 13 Residenial and Hospitality - Suleiman Arab Mixed Development
projects.name: Suleiman Arab Mixed Development
description: This mixed use development aims to be the first of its kind in its context in Amour Street Colombo. The design is intricately planned to achieve its vast brief on an extremely constrained site.The building is lifted up one floor allowing for the complex vehicular circulation and access that needs to be managed in a building of this nature. The hotel, Conference and mall parking and access are segregated from the apartment parking access to allow for smooth flow and value addition to the apartments.The mall, although at the first floor is directly accessible off the street through the grand staircase. This enhances the commercial value of the space.Hotel pool and recreation is located in a mid-level sky lobby while the dedicated recreation area for the apartments is located at the roof top level.The development offers 360 degree views of the city and the Colombo Port from all floors.

projects.name: House at Polhengoda Terrace
description: This 5 Bedroom house was designed where approximately half of the land was kept as a lawn as per the request of the client. Due to its urban setting an introverted spatial arrangement was introduced by focusing the internal spaces towards the central courtyard.
The external facades of the house are treated with timber fenestration creating a sense of privacy yet creating the transition of passage in terms of views and ventilation.
The courtyard acts on a stack effect, cooling the internal spaces and naturally ventilating them.
Exposed concrete, timber and white have been utilized to mix with the greenery of the context complimenting tropical modernism.

projects.name: Lake Gregory Apartments
projects.location: Upper Lake Road, Nuwara Eliya, Sri Lanka
description: The Apartment complex at Lake Gregory captures the essence of the colonial British architecture of Nuwara Eliya through the roof scape and scale. However these attributes have been made contemporary through the usage of materials and form. Each Apartment comprises open planning living and dining spaces with two bedrooms. Parking for each apartment is given at a semi basement level
Comprising just 8 units, each apartment frames the views of the Lake from the interior spaces. Texturally the interiors captures the essence of warmth through architectural tectonics and detailing.

projects.name: House at Malalasekere Terrace
description: This 4 Bedroom house was designed as an invert focused house. The house though situated on a small foot print has, a 2-car garage, 4 bedrooms, office room and living and dining space and service spaces. The living room is located in the 1st floor and faces a 1st floor level courtyard open to sky.

The building is placed on the site as two separate components where the private spaces a rear faced and the semipublic spaces face the road frontage. These two components are fused through the staircase that bridges these two parts of the building together but separates on either side through multiple courtyards.
This articulation of space interconnects the living room at a higher level with the trees on the road frontage and through the courtyard to the sky.
The dining space is on the ground level and opens to a second courtyard and a re garden space.

projects.name: Nestled Hideaway Villa
description: The villa lies on a 10.5 perch (265 square meter) land on a hill in Kandy city, Sri Lanka overlooking the historical Kandy Lake. A narrow elongated site nestled between two 4 level apartment buildings. The villa is approximately 70 feet in length and 30 feet in width. The requirements of the client subjected the land to maximum utilization.The foremost experience of the site is the beautiful view across Kandy Lake towards the Maligawa (the temple of the tooth relic of Lord Buddha) and the undulating landscape of greenery and Hills beyond.The villa designed as a 5 bedroom home with 5 bathrooms, pantry, kitchen, open plan living and dining, double carport, maid’s accommodation and toilet, powder room and also has an entertainment lounge and a 40 foot lap pool with a rooftop terrace that has now been further transformed to accommodate more rooms to be purposed as a boutique hotel.

projects.name: South Bolgoda Retreat
description: A weekend retreat for a family designed on the shores of the south Bolgoda Lake.

The design consists of two pavilions, one open planned servicing an open living space. The second pavilion interconnects with an open passageway consists of a pantry/ living and two bedrooms with attached bathrooms. Conceptually the design was derived through the fundamental elements of the trees that exists in the landscape which has been symbolically represented by verticality in the screens and the pillars of the structures. The horizontality of the landscape is represented in the linear form and the roof. The roof opens out towards the landscape at its perimeter, drawing the visitor in, when approaching the pavilion and visually exposing the visitor to the tranquil landscape from within the building.

projects.name: Meditation Center for Ranka-Ji Temple
description: A meditation centre and a retreat to teach and practice Theravada tradition Buddhist meditation in Japan.

The centre will be a place of learning on different Theravada Buddhist meditation methods and will be a centre for renowned meditation teachers to transfer knowledge of Theravada meditation methods and practises through the centre to Japanese society.
The design concept has been derived from the notion of mindfulness or focus of thought, the singular most important component of meditation.

This notion of concentration on singular objectivity calms the mind and rest the mind thereby strengthening it and developing clarity of thought and concentration which brings peace and joy to the individual which resonates to society.

The main meditation hall lies at the centre of the geometry. The roof concaves inwards towards the meditation hall representing one mindedness and focus where mindfulness occurs. From internal spaces the roof   juts out towards he landscape and sky radiating the energy that is derived through mediation.

projects.name: Residential Unit at Hampdon Lane
description: Located down Hampdon Lane in Wellawatte, the site is 8.0 perches in area. The requirement was a two unit apartment residential condo with a rentable commercial space on the ground floor. Therefor the design entails a ground floor commercial space and a three bedroom residential unit on the 1st and 2nd floors. The rooftop terrace acts as an urban garden that services the two apartment units.

As the site faces a very busy residential and commercial mixed zone street the design focuses on a façade that retains privacy for the inhabitants as well as brings in natural light and ventilation. In order to achieve this, a green screen has been developed on the façade where planters grow foliage that block out the western sun as well as filters the dust and noise from the street below. The façade also acts as a system of filtration in terms of privacy where operable panels are top hung on the façade for the inhabitants to open and close as necessary to create views and vistas to the street below and beyond.

projects.name: House at Wimala Vihare Road
description: Located down Wimala Vihare Road in Nawala, the site is 8.0 perches in area. The requirement was a three bedroom house for a family of three where the parents are doctors. Security was a paramount requirement as a large part of the day the house was not occupied due to the profession of the inhabitants.

The house is designed with a double height living and dining space that is intersected with a triple height open to sky courtyard. The courtyard acts as a wind funnel, constantly cooling the interior spaces due to the stack effect.

The roof top space that occupies an office, gym and a utility area opens out to two terraces that brings in light and ventilation. The facade of the front elevation that faces a private street has been treated with vertical timber fenestrations to give privacy to the internal spaces from buildings across the street.

projects.name: House at Kalinga Place
description: This luxury 16,000 sq.ft house is designed as a tropical climatic filter while remaining minimalist and contemporary.The house is designed with operable screens, double layered façades and courtyards to enhance its interaction and response to the tropical environment.The house includes a rooftop lap pool, pavilion and cinema. These elements are provided while maintaining a minimal and clean spatial character.The inverted pitched roof brings a light weight and unique character to the design that redefines tropical modernism.

projects.name: House One
projects.location: House One, Woodland Avenue, Colombo, Sri Lanka
description: Located in Kohuwela, the site is 6.79 perches in area. With limitations of 10 foot setbacks in the front and rear the house has been designed and built on a building footprint of less than 3.5 perches. The house consists of four Bed-rooms with attached Bathrooms, a Pantry and a Kitchen, open plan Living/Dining, a TV room and Rooftop terrace. The design utilizes maximum natural light and ventilation achieved by the use of sliding glass windows, routers and a central stairwell core that acts as a climate moderator taking out warmer air from the lower levels through the roof top level thus continuously cooling the building.

projects.name: The Trees Apartments
description: Elegantly designed 12 Bespoke units with views of greenery and the Kandy Lake. Spread out on four levels Each level consists of three private Apartments.

An apartment consists of three bedrooms with one apartment with attached bathrooms and two apartments with master toilet attached and a common toilet,  open plan Living and dinning serviced by a pantry. Maids or utility room consists of a terrace toilet. Each apartment has a staggered design in its formation to create privacy. Added privacy has been obtained through the introduction of green screens on the edge of the terraces.
Dedicated parking, standby Generator, 24 Hour security, Passenger lift, overhead water tanks and pump room for uninterrupted water and a roof top terrace garden are some of the utilities provided.

projects.name: Mahamaya Apartments
description: Mahamaya Apartments was designed on a 15 perch block facing a canal close to The kandy Lake. The land modulation was kept to a minimal. The project consists of 7 unite of 3 bedroom apartments, each with own dedicated parking and utilities.

The concept for the design was derived from the fenestrations that are common in ancient Kandyan architecture. The duality of light and privacy has been represented by the use of fenestration in the faced and in the internal spaces. The roof design represents a kandyan roof in an inverted form thus represents the vernacular but within a contemporary approach.
The exterior walls have been treated with bespoke  cement tiles of which the pattern has been derived from the ancient Dumbara mat weaving patterns unique to the Kandyan crafts heritage.

projects.name: Ocean View Condo
description: The project is a 28 unit 2 bedroom condominium complex. The Condominiums each have their own parking provision with common accessibility to vertical transportation through two lift and a common stairwell. A rooftop infinity pool and entertainment Terrace as well as a standby generator and a gym are shared amenities of the inhabitants. The site offers views towards the Indian Ocean and is west facing. Therefore dual layer fenestrations have been designed to moderate the harsh afternoon light yet bringing in the natural sea breeze as and when required.

projects.name: Boutique Hotel Kandy
description: This unique property lies in the most important viewpoint of Kandy City, with paneromic views of the Kandy Lake, the Shri Dalada Maligawa and the hinterland of the central hills beyond. Designed on a limited 25 perch property, the boutique hotel which is sevel levels consists of 30 rooms, a lounge, restaurant, infinity pool, yoga space, roof top bar, basement parking, a spa and a business center as well as three unique suites consisting of infinity pools that capture the view of the kandy city below.

The design while accommodating to the requirements of a boutique hotel was thought through as not to represent the current built environment of the context which is polluting the green environment by not being sensitive. Therefore the design is an anti-response to the current status of the existing built environment and a sensitive repose to the mountainous green environment which it lies on.

Therefore the exterior skin has been treated with a steel framework that breaks the monotony of the façade to fragments to which planting pods have been introduced to feed in vines and natural flora which in time would engulf the building into greenery. Therefore the building visually would be a sensitive representation of the forested mountainous landscape overtly, but internally would be a bespoke boutique hotel.
